lg.l: A man wth expence & infinite Toyle
By planting & dunging enobled his Soil
where fruits of ye best the overtast tast did invite
And uniform order still courted ye Sight
No degenerate weed ye ground did produce
But all things aforded for beauty & use
Till from ye Dunghill transplanted while yet but a seed
A Nettle rear'd up his inglorious head
The gardner would wisely have rooted him up
To stop ye encrease of a barbarous Crop
But ye Master forbad him & after ye fashion
of foolish good Nature & blind Moderation
Forbore him thro pity & chose ye much rather
To ask him Some questions first how he came thither
Kind Sr quoth ye Nettle a Stranger J come
a Wanderer thro conscience J relinquishd my Home
Cause I would not subscribe to a Mistery dark
That ye N. of all Trees was ye Jesuits Bark
An erroneous Tenet J know Sr that you
No more then my self will allow to be true
To you J for Refuge and sanctuary del ?comesue
There's none So renownd for compassion as you
and tho in some things J may differ from these
The rest of your fruitfull and beautifull Trees
as your digging & dunging my nature much harms
and J cannot comply wth your Garden in forms
Yet J and our family (after our fashion
will peaceably stick to our own Education
Be pleasd to allow us a place for to rest in
For ye rest of your trees we will never molest them
a kind Shelter to me and protection aford
we'll do you no harm J give you my word
The good man was soon movd wth a plausible Tale
So Fraud on good Nature does often prevail
He welcoms his guest gives him free toleration
Jn ye midst of his garden to take up his Station
and into his Bosom does his enemy bring
He little suspected the Nettle could Sting
Till flush'd wth Success & Strength to be feard
around him a Numerous offspring he reard
Then the master grew sensible what he had done
And fain would have had his new Guest to be gone
But now 'twas too late to bid him turn out
a wellrooted possession allready was gott
The old Trees decayd and in their Room grew
a stubborn, rank, pestilent turbulent Crew
The master who first the young brood had admitted
They Stung like ungrates and left him unpityed
No help from mannuring or planting was found
The weeds had eat up ye Heart of ye Ground
Now all weeds are lett in and none they refuse
That would Joyne to opose ye Good man of ye House
Thus one nettle uncropt increas'd to such store
That was nothing but weeds which was Garden beforeX85-600L
